abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Flood Emergency
            Recovery Project for Mozambique was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was modest, and the Bank and borrower performance
            were both satisfactory. The lessons learned found that it
            was important to mobilize a multisectoral team at an early
            stage to produce the macroeconomic, sectoral damage, and
            reconstruction assessment. Sharing the analytical documents,
            such as the damage assessment and the macroeconomic
            evaluation with donors and Governments contributes to a
            common understanding of the dimensions involved. Promote
            partnership in an open and transparent manner. Coordinate
            and leverage external assistance from the international
            community for reconstruction. Field negotiations with
            quality control and legal staff permitted a smooth process
            in the emergency project.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Flood Emergency Recovery Project
            will assist the Government implement, and maintain
            macroeconomic stability, through the financing of import
            costs, associated with rebuilding social, and economic
            infrastructure, and, re-establish production levels in
            response to the damage caused by the recent floods, and
            cyclones. The project will provide immediate
            quick-disbursing finance for: 1) construction materials,
            electricity and fuel needed for rehabilitation of physical
            infrastructure, including the rehabilitation of transport,
            water, sanitation, power, and buildings, and recuperation of
            private enterprises; 2) agricultural inputs, equipment, and
            materials needed to re-establish agricultural outputs; 3)
            livestock, animal products, and veterinary medicines; 4)
            medical supplies, and equipment needed for health facilities
            damaged by the floods; 5) school supplies, and equipment to
            restore educational facilities damaged, or destroyed; and,
            6) machinery, and equipment for commercial, and industrial
            companies. No disbursements will be made to cover luxury
            goods, nor military equipment. The credit will finance one
            hundred percent of the foreign costs of imports, and
            consultants, and eighty percent of the local costs of
            consultant services, including audits.
